results.firPara: Fifa has revealed the ticket prices for the 2018 World Cup, with the cost of the cheapest tickets available for foreign fans increasing more than 16% since 2014.
results.secPara: The most affordable tickets for group stage games will sell for $105 (£80), a $15 (£11) increase on the equivalent tickets in Brazil two years ago. The most expensive category one tickets for the final retail at $1,100 (£841), up from $990 (£650) for the Rio de Janeiro showpiece two years ago – a rise of £191, or just over 11%.
results.webTitle: Fifa reveals steep World Cup ticket price rises for Russia 2018

results.firPara: Fabricio Coloccini will return home to Argentina to join San Lorenzo after eight years with Newcastle United, with the north-east club announcing their captains contract had been terminated by mutual consent.
results.secPara: The move back to his home country has been long rumoured, with a move to the Primera División club mooted as far back as November 2013 when Coloccini said I would like to return as soon as possible.
results.webTitle: Fabricio Coloccini set for San Lorenzo after Newcastle terminate contract

results.firPara: Got a minute? Digest the best of our latest coverage from Euro 2016 as Iceland are welcomed home and Bale and Ronaldo prepare for battle
results.webTitle: The Euro 2016 minute: Iceland given heroes' welcome home

results.firPara: • Holland international made 11 appearances for Welsh club while on loan
results.secPara: Swansea have confirmed the signing of Leroy Fer from Queens Park Rangers for an undisclosed fee. The Holland international midfielder has signed a three-year contract after impressing manager Francesco Guidolin while on loan last season. He made 11 appearances for the club, who are his third in English football.
results.webTitle: Leroy Fer makes permanent Swansea move following loan from QPR

results.firPara: • Arsenal manager admits he was shocked by decision to leave EU
results.secPara: Arsène Wenger has admitted he was shocked by Britains decision to leave the European Union and has predicted the terms of Brexit could dictate the future of the Premier League.
results.webTitle: Arsène Wenger: terms of Brexit could dictate future of Premier League

results.firPara: José Mourinho brought a list of debutants and pointed barbs at Louis van Gaal for his first press conference as Manchester United manager
results.secPara: • Mourinho wants everything as United unveil new manager
results.webTitle: José Mourinho's Manchester United unveiling – as it happened!

results.firPara: The lanky striker found life tough in Columbus. But then he moved to the Israeli Premier League, started scoring goals, and has been linked with an Israel call-u
results.secPara: To Aaron Schoenfeld, this right here looks and feels like a rest Tel Aviv, Israel, to eastern Tennessee. Columbus, Ohio, to Georgia. Parents. Friends. Colleagues. Grandparents. Short stops in familiar locales after a whirlwind first half of the year. A hello here, a goodbye there, as he attempts to cram in as many close ones before the itinerary takes him back to the Middle East. The 26-year-old Knoxville native has barely had a rest since December 2014, and this is it flitting between states before pre-season training starts back in Tel Aviv on 5 July.
results.webTitle: Aaron Schoenfeld: the striker who quit MLS and found success in Israel

results.firPara: • Mourinho states ambitions and swipes at Louis van Gaal in bullish appearance
results.secPara: A bullish José Mourinho stated he wants to win the title, get the team playing well and promote youth for Manchester United, during an official unveiling as manager in which the Portuguese also aimed a barb at Louis van Gaal by being clear there will be no hiding behind philosophies.
results.webTitle: José Mourinho unveiled as Manchester United manager: ‘I want everything’

results.firPara: The Euro 2016 semi-finals are on Wednesday and Thursday, with Portugal facing Wales and Germany up against France. Which teams will make it to the final?
results.webTitle: Who will win the Euro 2016 semi-finals: Portugal v Wales and Germany v France?

results.firPara: The Milan president, Silvio Berlusconi, has confirmed that he will sell the seven-time European champions to Chinese investors and expects to receive €400m (£338m) over the next two years.
results.secPara: Berlusconi, who bought the club in 1986, has been negotiating for more than a year with various interested parties but is now confident that a deal will now be completed after he was released from hospital on Tuesday after heart surgery.
results.webTitle: Milan’s Silvio Berlusconi confirms sale of club to Chinese investors
